Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2009 01:10PM leighannmarie wrote: Being BRCA + puts you at higher risk for ovarian cancer as well.  You should be going to a high risk breast treatment center.  Did you get genetic couseling when you had the test done?  Staying healthy, good diet and exercise are great but, won't necessarily protect you from getting cancer.
Posts.Title: 20 and scared out of my mind!!! jenamae mbarnes

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2009 05:37PM leighannmarie wrote: This is suspicious for cancer but, not diagnostic.  They will want to biopsy this.  Lobulated with indistinct margins rules out a simple cyst.  Hypoechoic means there are solid particles in there.  Vascularity means there is some evidence of a blood flow to the mass.  Did the radiologist talk to you after the US?  Waiting and worrying is SO dificult but, unfortunately you wont know for sure until they can take a tissue sample.  Best wishes for a benign result!
Posts.Title: Ok...any idea what this means? Willow_1647 thenewme

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2010 03:28PM leighannmarie wrote: Hey Janina.  Interesing that they did lumpectomy alone and node biopsy later.  Why are they doing 2 surgeries?  Do you know if they are doing a sentinal node biopsy or axillary dissection?  12mm is 1.2 cm.  Much smaller than 3cm.  If your tumor is in your nodes or it is Her2 positive you will need chemo.  If it is not in the nodes you should have an oncotype test.  This will tell the doctor if chemo will be of benefit for you.  I turned White when my surgeon told me to be prepared because I Might need chemo.  I did, and it was a devastating day for me when I was told.  But, here I am done with chemo and have moved on to radiation.  Unfortunately young women like us frequently have cancers that require chemo.  I am glad you found us here.  There are a lot of great women here to help you no matter what your journey brings!
Posts.Title: Diagnosed today! Janina sweatyspice

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2010 03:36PM leighannmarie wrote: If the sentinal node is negative they don't remove more nodes.  This surgery is done to allow women with negative nodes to avoid more extensive surgery that carries more risk for problems like lymphadema.  If the sentinal node is positive they want to take more nodes to check them for cancer.  This will help them determine your prognosis and treatment.  If there are 4 or more positive nodes then axillary radiation is recommended.
Posts.Title: positive lymph nodes alison34 Mouse6

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2010 03:54PM leighannmarie wrote: Good luck with the follow up.  I'd say chances a very very good that he biopsies were correct and negative. They get quite a bit of tissue with these biopsies and they would have to really miss the mass to get false negatives 2 times.  They should have put in little clips that will show up on mammo that will mark the area that was biopsied.     Follow ups are good but, don't drive yourself crazy.  If something doesn't feel right to you get it checked out and get another opinion if you are still not comfortable.

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2010 11:49AM leighannmarie wrote: I felt the same way.  I told my doc that when I went for the markings.  He said a lot of people feel that way.  The night before my treatment began I cried my self to sleep.  I am halfway done now and am getting a bit sore and red but I am not as scared anymore.
Posts.Title: Wanting to chicken out of radiation... lotstolivefor helena1018

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2010 12:27PM leighannmarie wrote: There can still be microscopic cancer left behind after surgery.  Especially if it traveled to the lymph node.  They do not remove the whole lymph sinus with surgery.  Most likely there are still cells left and radiation kills them.  Chemo also does not always kill all cancer cells.It can happen but it is not a given.  Clear margins are great but does not mean all cells are gone.
Posts.Title: Why do I need radiation? June2268 o2bhealthy

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2009 04:19PM leighannmarie wrote: This can happen but it is not common.  If the needle was not in the malignant tumor you could get a false negative.  There are tumors that may have atypical cells but more tissue is needed to determine if it is malignant or benign.  Was the lump pretty small?  My aunt recently had a lumpectomy because although the tumor was thought to be benign there was a 20% chance for that type of tumor to have malignant cells.  My tumor was not hard and it was malignant.  A lot of things can cause a hard lump.  The feel of a tumor is not diagnostic.

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2009 08:48PM leighannmarie wrote: Don't wait!  Go get this checked out.  It may be nothing but, inflammatory BC is very aggressive.  You need to make sure this is not what is going on.

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2009 01:44AM leighannmarie wrote: They always want to do a follow up.  It is an opportunity for you to ask questions and they can see if there is still something going on and things have healed properly.  Yeah, sounds like they think it is a skin tag.  You will need to talk to your doc more if you are not confident with this diagnosis.
Posts.Title: Pathology Back....Help Needed layla26 Polyana

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2009 06:32PM - edited Oct 24, 2009 06:38PM by leighannmarie Your tumor is grade 3 or high grade.  She may have said T2 a tumor 2cm or larger. Stage II is also a tumor that is 2 - 5 cm and has or has not spread to the lymph nodes.  Stage I is less than 2cm and has not spread to the nodes.  You Will lose your hair if you have chemo which I suspect you will.  The drugs used to treat BC make you lose your hair.  Unfortunately, younger women often have more agressive ER- PR- (hormone receptor negative) cancers.  These types of cancers generally require chemo.  Radiation is used for most BC and DCIS. Mastectomy is an option if you dont want radiation but depending on your lymph node status you may need radiation regardless of surgery. Medullary is a type of BC.  It does not make your diagnosis any worse.  You have Ductal Cell Carinoma and Medullary Cancer.
Posts.Title: Pathology Is Back - Cancer Lifeisbeautiful jenn3

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2010 04:54PM leighannmarie wrote: Did you get your report?  Do you know your  Bi-Rad score? The highest score is a 5 and means it is very likely cancer (95% probability with classic cancer characteristics) but, yeah you can't tell 100% without a biopsy. Cancers are never benign but, there are various types and grades of breast cancers some, highly curable and non agressive some highly agressive.  Best of luck to you.  I hope that the doctor is wrong.
